Barbados: The Codrington College (grammar school), named after the late Christopher Codrington is established by the Anglican Church.
Belgium:
Battle of Fontenoy
Battle of Melle
Fall of Ghent
Siege of Ostend
France: The Dauphin Louis of France marries Infanta Maria Teresa Rafaela of Spain at the Chapel of Versailles. Yew Tree Ball: Masked ball given by the Louis XV in the Grand Gallery of the Chateau of Versailles, on the occasion of the marriage of Louis, Dauphin of France with Maria Teresa, Infanta of Spain. Fifteen thousand people attended including Jeanne Antoinette Poisson who met with the King for a second time. War of the Austrian Succession: French forces defeat an Anglo-Dutch-Hanoverian army at the Battle of Fontenoy; Louis XV, and his son, the Dauphin, were present at the battle. Jean-Baptiste de Machault d'Arnouville becomes Controller-General of Finances at the age of forty-four.
Germany: Battle of Hohenfriedberg: A Prussian force led by Frederick the Great decisively defeated the allied armies of Austria and Saxony, halting the attempted reconquest of Silesia. Silesian Wars: Prussia, Austria and Saxony signed the Treaty of Dresden, confirming Prussia's sovereignty over Silesia and ending the war.
Indinesia: Pakubuwono II established a new kraton in Sala village and established Surakarta Sunanate.
Japan: Yoshimune retired, leaving his public office to his eldest son Tokugawa Ieshige, although he maintained some influence in the affairs of state.
Philippine: Archbishop Juan Arrechederra of Manila becomes acting Governor-General (1745–1750).
